text: 1.) What is the main point of contention between anthropologists and economists regarding gift-giving?

options.text: Anthropologists view gift-giving as a positive social process, while economists consider it a waste of resources.
Anthropologists and economists both agree that gift-giving is a waste of resources.
Anthropologists argue that gift-giving is a waste of resources, while economists see it as a positive social process.
Anthropologists and economists both consider gift-giving a positive social process.

text: 2.) According to Waldfogel (1993), what does the term '‘the deadweight loss of Christmas’’ refer to?

options.text: The loss of interest in gift-giving during the Christmas season.
The tendency of gift-givers to overspend, resulting in recipients not appreciating the gifts as much as expected.
The financial burden of buying gifts during the holiday season.
The loss of emotional connection between gift-givers and recipients during Christmas.

text: 3.) Why do gift-givers tend to overspend on gifts, according to the passage?

options.text: They believe that expensive gifts convey stronger signals of thoughtfulness and consideration.
They want to impress the recipients with the cost of the gift.
They are unaware of the actual preferences of the recipients.
They want to create a lasting impression on the recipients.

text: 4.) What is the psychological explanation proposed in the passage for the overspending problem of gift-givers?

options.text: Gift-givers want to impress the recipients with expensive gifts.
Gift-givers assume that the price of the gift is directly related to the recipient's appreciation.
Gift-givers are unaware of the economic implications of their spending habits.
Gift-givers believe that recipients will appreciate gifts regardless of their price.
